ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Ototoxicity
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: The patient has a history of recent treatment for a severe infection with an unknown medication (likely an aminoglycoside), followed by sudden tinnitus and high-frequency hearing loss. The pattern of extended high-frequency loss with preservation of lower frequencies is classic for early ototoxicity.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Noise-Induced Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: High-frequency hearing loss and tinnitus are consistent with noise exposure, but the sudden onset linked specifically to the medical treatment makes ototoxicity more probable.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss (Idiopathic)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Sudden onset of hearing issues fits, but SSNHL is typically unilateral and not bilateral. The clear temporal link to medication use points away from an idiopathic cause.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To ensure ear canals are clear and tympanic membranes are normal.
Crucial for detecting ototoxicity, which often affects frequencies >8 kHz first.
To assess outer hair cell function, which is the primary site of lesion in ototoxicity.
To rule out middle ear pathology.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The evaluation reveals normal hearing sensitivity in the standard frequency range (250-8000 Hz) but significant sensorineural hearing loss in the extended high frequencies (10-16 kHz). DPOAEs are absent in the higher frequencies, corroborating cochlear damage. This profile is highly consistent with ototoxicity.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal thresholds (0-5 dB HL) for 250-8000 Hz. Extended high-frequency testing shows elevated thresholds at 10 kHz and no response at 12-16 kHz bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Excellent Word Recognition Scores (Right: 97%, Left: 94%). SRTs align with PTA.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Type A tympanograms bilaterally, indicating normal middle ear function.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (DPOAEs)
tests.result_summary: Present and robust 0.5-4 kHz; amplitudes drop sharply and are absent/reduced above 4-6 kHz.

proposed_items: Identify the specific medication used (consult with prescribing physician) to confirm ototoxicity.
Implement tinnitus management strategies (sound enrichment, masking).
Advise on hearing conservation (hearing protection in noise).
Monitor hearing thresholds serially to check for stability.
counseling_actions: Explain that the tinnitus and difficulty in noise are caused by damage to the very high-pitch hearing cells, even though standard hearing tests look normal.
Discuss the connection between the recent antibiotic treatment and the hearing changes.
Counsel that the high-frequency loss is likely permanent.
Provide education on protecting residual hearing from noise exposure.

red_flags_present: History of recent severe infection and medication use

escalation.rationale_short: To document the adverse reaction to the medication and prevent future administration of the same class of drugs (e.g., aminoglycosides) if possible.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing thresholds for stability and assess tinnitus impact.

expected_outcome: Extended high-frequency hearing loss is likely permanent.
Tinnitus may persist but habituation is expected with management.
Standard frequency hearing should remain stable barring further noise or chemical insults.
